Context: To characterize the structure and dynamics of heliconiine microbiomes, we used field collections of wild butterflies, 16S rRNA gene sequencing, quantitative PCR, and shotgun metagenomics.
We collected 214 wild adult butterflies, representing 23 species and subspecies of Heliconiini, and characterized their microbiomes by 16S rRNA gene sequencing.
While many adult Lepidoptera microbiome studies have used reared, captive specimens (6, 12, 13, 22, 27), these may give a biased picture of microbial community structure in the wild (11).

The wild adult butterflies used for whole-body microbiome sequencing were collected from seven locations in Panama and Ecuador from May to August 2014 (more detail is provided in the “Collection_localities.txt” file at https://figshare.com/projects/Heliconius_butterfly_microbiomes/ 70520).
Variation of chemical compounds in wild Heliconiini reveals ecological factors involved in the evolution of chemical defenses in mimetic butterflies.
Given their potential interactions with gut bacteria and relevance to host fitness, more targeted analyses of butterflyassociated microeukaryote diversity are clearly warranted.
Effects of the protozoan parasite Ophryocystis elektroscirrha on the fitness of monarch butterflies (Danaus plexippus).
